Title: Explosion and fire of hazardous chemicals storage hangar
LessonsLearned: Failures found (as also found by ARPA in the report of the consultant of the court)<BR><BR>1 - Incomplete knowledge of non declared substances (arsenic trioxide cas 1327-53-3)&nbsp; and other substances which were not in the inventory (like sodium chlorate)stored inside storage hangar in. During the post accident phase certain out of specification products were found considered as waste products by the company&nbsp; and which were not recorded in the records of the storage hangar (ex. Arsenic oxide etc.) Between the substances found some present clear risks, hazards and reciprocal incompatibilities.<BR>- 2. Need to improve the product flow and storage management system of incompatible substances stored in the storage.<BR>- 3. Need to revise the Safety Management System thoroughly, concerning the storage, the product flow and the registration of handled products, and the specific training of the storage personnel on the hazards of the handled substances.<BR><BR>Measures taken<BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;the company declares <BR>-to have taken measures for controlling the quantity and the compatibility of stored products and in particular hato have prepared a detailed layout and end-use indication <BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;To develop a specific software to control the maximum amount of stored hazardous substances according to the lower tier thresholds<BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;To have reorganised the management of the company by nominating a new manager for the chemicals sector<BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;To increase the storage facility by building 2 new storage hangars<BR><BR>Programmed measures<BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;revision of the quality and safety management systems and following training of the management personnel involved<BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;improvement of the procedures and of the equipment for verifying the hazard potential of substances, management and analysis of safety data sheets and control of the quantities of stored hazardous substances.<BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Definition of a compatibility matrix of hazardous substances and identification of the appropriate storage areas<BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Improvement of the control procedures concerning the application of operational procedures and technical instructions by the operational personnel<BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Intensification of information and training of the operational personnel<BR><BR>Further to the above described measure the Consultant of the competent court counsels to:<BR>- Integrate an operative procedure for the risk and incompatibility evaluation of substances previous to the issue buying orders<BR>- store incompatible substances in separate storage compartments<BR>- set up an internal team for the analysis of incompatibilities of substances responsible for the lay-out and in particular during handling inside the company<BR>- reduction of rhe storage amounts inside the storage facility also by delocalisation of the products<BR>- define a specific procedure for the chlorite dissolution which does not foresee the previous opening of the drums.
EmergencyResponce_Descr: Onsite Emergency Response<BR>Intervention of onsite emergency team, evacuatiion of the personnel of the entire establishment, use of fire monitors and other extinguishing means (powder, CO2 etc) waiting for the intervention of the public fire brigades. Activation of the automatic water curtains for the protection of the office building.<BR>Securing of the area and collection and disposal of the chemicals remaining in the storage hangar. by an external company.<BR><BR>Offsite Emergency services<BR>Intervention of fire brigade teams from different provincial commands - 39 interventions by teams started from various provincial commands between 27/07 and 29/07<BR>Fire extinguishing operations, made difficult by the toxic smoke and the potential incompatibility with extinguishing water, request of intervention of a specialised team;<BR>- once main fires extinguished, water curtains for the abatement of toxic fumes, extinguishing operations of minor fires, the loss of containment of many chemical containers in the storage hangar was detected<BR>Research of the dispersed operator resulting dead.<BR><BR>The comunal authorities of Fagnano Olona proceeded in Informing the neighbouring population, counselling to stay inside andclose windows and doors etc.<BR><BR>Closure of roads nearby the accident site<BR><BR>ARPA was charged by the judicial authoritieswith the post accident monitoring and start of the accident investigation<BR><BR>Decontamination<BR>Disposal of extinguishing water collected in the retention basin (100 m3) partly in the onsite waste water treatment plant (chemical and physical treatment) and partly transferred to external waste-water treatment facilities. In total 130 m3 of waste water originating from the accident was disposed.<BR><BR>Disposal and remediation<BR>Securing of hangar A, demolition of instable structural elements, rebuilding and repair of the damaged structures.<BR>Due to problems related to the authorisation process for the disposal of hazardous chemicals, the company charged with the disposal of the hazardous waste products originated from the accident had not been able in date of this report to start with the process of disposal of these substances.<BR><BR>

AccidentDescription: Explosion and fire of hazardous chemicals storage hangar (hangar A), caused by the release of sodium chlorite from metal drums, hit by an erroneous operation of a forklift. The explosion, triggering a domino effect involving other drums and bags containing hazardous chemical products present in the hangar, caused the collapse of the hangar due to the pressure wave. The collapse of the structure caused the death of the operator crushed by the debris. The pressure wave injured a second operator who was hospitalised and dismissed in the evening. The pressure wave damaged also the adjoining solids storage hangar, causing the collapse of part of the structure, and ignited some small fires due to spark projection. The fire brigade declared that a mushroom cloud developed having initially a clear colour (presumably deriving from dust generated by the collapsing hangar) and then changed into black smoke deriving from the combustion of the chemical products,<BR>Activation of the onsite emergency response plan and immediate intervention of the external fire brigade teams from different command posts of the province of Varese and other provinces. The Regional Environmental Protection Agency (ARPA)of Lombardy intervened for monitoring the air quality in the area nearby the collapsed hangar. <BR>- Securing of the establishment and containment of the sewage system.<BR>The fires were almost extinguished in the afternoon. Activation of the offsite emergency response plan with intervention of police forces and local authorities.<BR>Successive monitoring of waste waters in the post emergency phase.

Causes_Description: Storage hangar for hazardous chemicals <BR>The explosion and fire occurred in the storage area of comburent agents, and in particular in the storage area for sodium chlorite pellets in the form of crystalline powder, in this area there two elevators were operating with two operators (one of which deceased and the other was injured)<BR>The reacted product (sodium chlorite) was released by one or more metallic drums containing 50 kg each.<BR><BR>Wrong operation of a forklift in the comburent area causing the impact of the forklift with drums containing sodium chlorite causing the release of sodium chlorite.<BR>Ignition of the product, 2 operators escaping towards the fire shelters, first deflagrations one of which projecting one of the operators outside of the hangar injured, whereas the other is killed by the debris of the collapsing building (1 fatality)&nbsp; <BR><BR>Determination of exact accident causes will be possible only after the conclusion of the accident investigation, which is in process.<BR><BR>The post -accident investigations performed by ARPA (Regional Agency for the Protection of the Environment) determined the presence of incompatible substances in the storage hangar, and in particular the presence of peracetic acid CAS&nbsp; 79-21-0. in the explosion point. Peracetic acid can cause an explosive reaction when getting into contact with sodium chlorite (CAS 7758-19-2).<BR>According to the NIOSH Material Data Safety Sheet sodium chlorite decomposes at 180-200Â°C producing toxic and corrosive fumes. It could be assumed that the sodium chlorite decomposed due to the initial violent exothermic reaction with the acid and then by the high temperature reached by the initial explosive reaction. The company declared that 30 t of sodium chlorite were destroyed by the accident, representing the entire quantity stored.<BR>The company admitted the presence of a 1000 l storage tank of peracetic acid at 15% outside of the storage hangar, - the tank was found damaged in proximity of the collapsed hangar,&nbsp; arguing further that the presence of peracetic acid in the explosion point could be justified by the extinguishing water used by the fire brigades.<BR>On the other hand all elements collected by ARPA indicate non correct management procedures of hazardous materials inside the storage facility.<BR><BR>These statements are however still to be evaluated in the judicial procedure which is still in process.<BR>

Consequence_Description: 1 fatality<BR>1 person injured<BR><BR>Onsite material damage<BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;structural damages to hangar A, partial collapse of the structure, destruction of the electrical supply system, destruction of 3 forklifts, loss of almost all chemicals stored in the hangar, destruction of sulphur acid dilution equipment, damages to the adjoining office building,&nbsp; etc-<BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Estimated material damage 3.200.000 EUR of which 810.000 EUR of loss of stored products<BR><BR>Offsite material damage<BR>No offsite material damage caused by the pressure wave of the explosion<BR><BR>Environmental damage<BR>Concentration of hazardous substances in the air<BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;no relevant concentrations (mainly ammonia and cyanidric acid) were detected offsite while monitoring during and after the accident<BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;ammonia 30 ppm 15 m from the explosion point, 2 ppm at the limits of the site<BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;cyanidric acid , 1 - 2 ppm 15 m from the explosion point, 0,3 ppm at the limits of the site<BR>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;while onsite the use of filter-masks was needed during 48 hours.
